I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling sad. One technique of the UM system that might be helpful for you in this situation is note-taking. This involves silently noting the experience of sadness when it arises. For example, you might note "sadness, sadness" in your mind as you become aware of the emotion. By doing this, you can develop a greater level of sensory clarity and mindfulness towards your emotions, while at the same time practicing equanimity in the face of difficult emotions. This technique can help you to learn to accept your emotions without becoming overwhelmed by them, allowing you to relate to yourself with greater compassion and understanding.

It is the concept of "no-self" in Buddhism. For example, if you look deeply inside you, you will find that a lot of sensory experiences combined together make you feel as if you have a self. I feel very painful. What should I do?

I am very sorry to hear that you are feeling very painful. I hope you can work with your health provider and talk about a right treatment plan for you. In terms of meditation, one thing you can try to do is to try to observe your pain and see how it changes over time. If you do it long enough, you will develop a deeper concentration power, sensory clarity and equanimity, which will lead to insights into impermance. This will ultimately lead to enlightenment. May you be healthy and be less painful.
